glossary.commercial: Any farm that is raising animals intended to make a profit, irrespective of its size (number of animals present).
glossary.compartment: A physically defined unit or area where one group of pigs is being kept (i.e. you can have multiple compartments of the same animal category). Often, physical contact is possible between the animals of different pens within this compartment.
glossary.establishment: The entire farm premises, including all indoor animal facilities and the entire outdoor area surrounding the farm. It includes premises with any number of pigs.
glossary.pen: The smallest unit in which pigs are being kept.
glossary.working_lines: A specific order in which the work on the establishment is carried out.
glossary.clean_area: The area of the production site with restricted access, i.e. where only animals from the farm, persons after they have applied the hygienic measures in the hygiene lock, and farm-specific materials and vehicles are allowed.
glossary.dirty_area: All other parts of the farm to which visitors, external vehicles, ... have access. The dirty area also includes the carcass storage facility.
glossary.health_advisor: Any person who comes to the farm to help improve animal health (e.g. nutritionists, consultants, etc.).
glossary.all_in_all_out: System where the animals that move to the same unit are moved there all at once and no new animals are introduced in the unit before it is emptied.

farm_profile.title: Farm Characteristics
farm_profile.description: Basic information about your farm (required first-time setup)

questions.text: Which of the following animal categories are present on the farm?
Are there, besides the pigs, any other farm animals present on your farm?
What other farm animal(s) is (are) present on your farm?
How many years of experience in keeping pigs does the person in charge have?
What is the number of people (full-time or part-time) that are taking care of the pigs?
How old (in years) is the oldest building in which pigs are being kept?
questions.help_text: If the building was renovated, give the age before the renovation.

questions.text: How old (in years) is the newest building in which pigs are being kept?
questions.help_text: If the building was renovated, give the age before the renovation.

focus_areas.name: Purchase & Transport
focus_areas.description: Prevent disease entry through animals and vehicles

questions.text: Are breeding pigs (sows/gilts/boars) purchased?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Purchasing breeding pigs from external sources significantly increases the risk of introducing infectious diseases to your herd, including PRRS, swine influenza, and other pathogens.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Establish strict supplier qualification criteria. Only purchase from farms with known health status and recent veterinary certifications. Implement mandatory quarantine period of at least 4 weeks.

questions.text: Are the breeding pigs (during the past 2 years) always bought from the same supplier?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Purchasing from multiple suppliers increases exposure to diverse disease sources and makes disease tracking more difficult.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Limit breeding pig purchases to one trusted supplier with consistent health records. Establish long-term partnership with certified disease-free farms.

questions.text: Whenever breeding pigs are bought from another farm, is the supplier's health status known before purchase?

options.text: Yes, the supplier's health status is higher than my own status
Yes, the supplier's health status is equal to my own status
Yes, the supplier's health status is lower than my own, but I take precautions measures
Yes, the supplier's health status is lower than my own and no precautions measures are taken

questions.help_text: A herd with a known health status is a herd from which it is known if it is free from specific diseases (e.g., scabies, PRRS, ...) or not. If the herd is free from specific diseases, it therefore also guarantees that the delivered products (animals) originating from this herd are also free of these diseases. The supplier's health status is higher than the one of the farm whenever the supplier has a certification that he is free from more diseases than the farm.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unknown supplier health status creates blind spots in your biosecurity chain and may introduce undetected diseases.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Require comprehensive health documentation before purchase, including recent disease testing, vaccination records, and veterinary health certificates.

questions.text: Is it verified (e.g. written document or other statements) whether the transport vehicle that brings the breeding pigs to the farm is cleaned and disinfected before loading?
questions.help_text: If the transport vehicle looks visually clean but the transporter cannot provide evidence of the cleaning and disinfection, select answer option "I don't know".

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unverified transport vehicle cleaning allows disease transmission from previous loads, potentially contaminating your incoming pigs.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Demand written proof of vehicle cleaning and disinfection. Consider using company-owned transport or certified livestock transporters only.

questions.text: How many times per year are breeding pigs delivered to your farm?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Frequent deliveries increase the number of potential disease exposure events and biosecurity breaches.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Consolidate deliveries to minimize farm access frequency. Plan purchases to reduce the number of delivery events per year.

questions.text: Are all new breeding pigs quarantined in an area separate from the rest of the herd?
questions.help_text: The quarantine area can be in the same building, but it should be completely separate (no physical contact) from the rest of the animals.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of quarantine allows immediate mixing of new animals with existing herd, risking rapid disease spread if new animals are infected.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Establish dedicated quarantine facility physically separated from main herd. Maintain strict quarantine protocols for minimum 4 weeks with health monitoring.

questions.text: Is strict all-in management practised in the quarantine area?
questions.help_text: All-in: all the animals that have to be quarantined are put into the quarantine area at the same moment. It's crucial that no new animals (coming from another farm) are introduced in the quarantine area before it is emptied.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Poor quarantine management (mixing batches, inadequate duration) defeats the purpose of isolation and allows disease transmission.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement strict all-in/all-out quarantine management. Never mix different batches. Ensure minimum 28-day quarantine with daily health checks.

questions.text: What is the minimum duration (in days) of the quarantine period that you applied in the last year?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Insufficient quarantine period (less than 4 weeks) may not allow enough time for disease incubation periods to manifest.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Extend quarantine to minimum 4 weeks (28 days). Consider longer periods for high-risk disease areas. Monitor for clinical signs daily.

questions.text: Is there a separate hygiene lock for the quarantine area?
questions.help_text: A hygiene lock is a facility, where among others, you can change into specific clothes/boots and clean/disinfect your hands.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared hygiene facilities between quarantine and main herd create direct contamination pathways for disease transmission.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install dedicated hygiene lock for quarantine area with separate clothing, footwear, and handwashing stations. Maintain strict separation protocols.

questions.text: Are piglets purchased?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Purchasing piglets introduces external pathogens and breaks the closed-herd biosecurity advantage.
risk_assessment.recommendation: If possible, transition to closed-herd production. If purchasing necessary, apply same strict biosecurity as breeding pig purchases.

questions.text: Are the piglets (during the past 2 years) always bought from the same supplier?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Multiple piglet suppliers multiply disease exposure risks and complicate disease source identification.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Source piglets from single, verified healthy supplier. Establish consistent supply partnership with regular health monitoring.

questions.text: Whenever piglets are bought from another farm, is the supplier's health status known before purchase?

options.text: Yes, the supplier's health status is higher than my own status
Yes, the supplier's health status is equal to my own status
Yes, the supplier's health status is lower than my own, but I take precautions measures
Yes, the supplier's health status is lower than my own and no precautions measures are taken

questions.help_text: A herd with a known health status is a herd from which it is known if it is free from specific diseases (e.g., scabies, PRRS, ...) or not. If the herd is free from specific diseases, it therefore also guarantees that the delivered products (animals) originating from this herd are also free of these diseases. The supplier's health status is higher than the one of the farm whenever the supplier has a certification that he is free from more diseases than the farm.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unknown piglet supplier health status creates uncertainty about disease introduction risks.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Verify supplier health status before purchase. Require vaccination records, health certificates, and recent disease testing results.

questions.text: Is it verified (e.g. written document or other statements) whether the transport vehicle that brings the piglets to the farm is cleaned and disinfected before loading?
questions.help_text: If the transport vehicle looks visually clean but the transporter cannot provide evidence of the cleaning and disinfection, select answer option "I don't know".

risk_assessment.risk_description: Contaminated transport vehicles can introduce pathogens even if source farm is healthy.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Verify transport vehicle cleaning and disinfection with written documentation. Inspect vehicles before loading.

questions.text: How many times per year are piglets delivered to your farm?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Frequent piglet deliveries increase biosecurity breach opportunities and disease exposure events.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Reduce delivery frequency through better planning and batch purchasing. Consolidate orders to minimize farm entry points.

questions.text: Does breeding occur naturally or artificially?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Natural breeding with external boars increases disease transmission risk through direct animal contact.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Consider artificial insemination to eliminate external boar contact. If natural breeding used, ensure boar health verification.

questions.text: Which boars are used for natural breeding?

options.text: Own boars that remain on the farm
Own boars that are housed on (a) different farm(s)
Breeding boars that are used on different farms

questions.help_text: If "Natural breeding" was chosen in question 15, go to question 18.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Using external boars for natural breeding introduces pathogens through direct physical contact.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Transition to farm-owned boars or artificial insemination. If external boars necessary, require health certificates and testing.

questions.text: Whenever semen is purchased from a farm/boar station, is the supplier's health status known before purchase?

options.text: Yes, the supplier's health status is higher than my own status
Yes, the supplier's health status is equal to my own status
Yes, the supplier's health status is lower than my own, but I take precautions measures
Yes, the supplier's health status is lower than my own and no precautions measures are taken

questions.help_text: A herd with a known health status is a herd from which it is known if it is free from specific diseases (e.g., scabies, PRRS, ...) or not. If the herd is free from specific diseases, it therefore also guarantees that the delivered products (animals) originating from this herd are also free of these diseases. The supplier's health status is higher than the one of the farm whenever the supplier has a certification that he is free from more diseases than the farm.

risk_assessment.risk_description: External semen sources may carry disease-causing organisms if quality control is inadequate.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Purchase semen only from certified AI centers with strict health monitoring and quality control programs.

questions.text: Is the establishment physically divided into a clean and dirty area?
questions.help_text: The clean area is the area of the production site with restricted access, i.e. where only animals from the farm, persons after they have applied the hygienic measures in the hygiene lock, and farm-specific materials and vehicles are allowed. The dirty area comprises all other parts of the farm to which visitors, external vehicles, ... have access.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of clean/dirty area separation allows unrestricted pathogen movement throughout the farm premises.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Establish clear physical boundaries between clean (animal) and dirty (external access) areas. Install signage and enforce strict protocols.

questions.text: Are slaughter pigs transported from your farm to the slaughterhouse?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Transporting slaughter pigs off-farm risks bringing back contamination from slaughterhouse environment.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Ensure proper vehicle cleaning protocols after transport. Consider dedicated transport vehicles that never return to farm buildings.

questions.text: Is the transport vehicle for the slaughter pigs empty before loading?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared transport vehicles carry contamination from other farms, creating cross-contamination risk.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use empty, cleaned vehicles only. Verify cleaning with documentation. Consider farm-owned dedicated transport.

questions.text: Is it verified (e.g. written document or other statements) whether the transport vehicle for the slaughter pigs is cleaned and disinfected before loading?
questions.help_text: If the transport vehicle looks visually clean but the transporter cannot provide evidence of the cleaning and disinfection, select answer option "I don't know".

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unverified vehicle cleaning allows pathogen survival and transmission between farms.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement mandatory vehicle inspection and cleaning verification before loading. Document all cleaning activities.

questions.text: Are sows transported from your farm either to other farms or to the slaughterhouse?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Sow transport increases disease exposure and stress-related health issues.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Minimize sow transport frequency. Ensure proper vehicle biosecurity when transport is necessary.

questions.text: Is the transport vehicle for the sows empty before loading?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Contaminated sow transport vehicles introduce pathogens from external sources.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Require empty, cleaned vehicles with verification documentation before loading sows.

questions.text: Is it verified (e.g. written document or other statements) whether the transport vehicle for the sows is cleaned and disinfected before loading?
questions.help_text: If the transport vehicle looks visually clean but the transporter cannot provide evidence of the cleaning and disinfection, select answer option "I don't know".

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of transport vehicle sanitation verification leaves biosecurity gaps.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement written vehicle cleaning verification system. Inspect vehicles before allowing farm access.

questions.text: Are piglets transported from your farm to other farms (e.g. to a finisher site)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Piglet transport exposes young, immunologically naive animals to external pathogens.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use dedicated, regularly sanitized transport for piglets. Minimize transport stress and duration.

questions.text: Is the transport vehicle for the piglets empty before loading?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared piglet transport vehicles carry disease risk from other farms.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Ensure vehicles are empty and cleaned before piglet loading. Verify cleaning documentation.

questions.text: Is it verified (e.g. written document or other statements) whether the transport vehicle for the piglets is cleaned and disinfected before loading?
questions.help_text: If the transport vehicle looks visually clean but the transporter cannot provide evidence of the cleaning and disinfection, select answer option "I don't know".

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unverified cleaning of piglet transport allows pathogen transmission.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Require and verify written cleaning protocols. Inspect vehicle cleanliness before loading.

questions.text: Does the driver have access to the animal holding areas and/or is direct contact with the animals possible when loading the animals (slaughter pigs, sows, piglets)?

options.text: Farmer and/or farm personnel is the driver, i.e. own transport

risk_assessment.risk_description: Driver access to animal areas creates direct contamination pathway from external environment.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Prohibit driver entry to animal areas. Establish loading areas at farm perimeter in dirty zone.

questions.text: Does the driver receive and wear farm-specific clothing and shoes?

options.text: The driver brings his/her own cleaned and disinfected clothing and shoes
The driver stays inside the transport vehicle

risk_assessment.risk_description: Drivers not using farm-specific clothing bring external contamination into animal areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Require drivers to use farm-provided clean clothing and footwear if they must enter farm premises.

questions.text: Are the pigs loaded from a separate loading area or directly from the pens/central corridor?
questions.help_text: The separate loading area (or loading bay) is a physically separated location where the animals are brought before/during loading.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Loading pigs from main facility increases contamination risk from transport vehicles entering clean areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Construct dedicated loading area at farm boundary in dirty zone. Prevent transport vehicles from entering clean areas.

questions.text: Are pigs ever returned to the pens (e.g. by walking back or by being placed back) after they were in the transport vehicle?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Returning pigs to pens after transport exposes entire group to external pathogens and defeats biosecurity measures.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Never return pigs to pens after loading for transport. Once loaded, pigs should not re-enter farm facilities.

questions.text: Is manure transported and disposed of through the dirty access road?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Manure removal through clean areas spreads contamination and pathogens throughout farm.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Design manure removal routes exclusively through dirty areas. Never allow manure transport through clean zones.

questions.text: Are farm-specific hoses for the removal of manure from the manure pit available on the farm (i.e. are hoses for the removal of manure available that always stay at the farm)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared manure equipment with other farms creates cross-contamination opportunities.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use farm-specific manure handling equipment only. Clean and disinfect any shared equipment before use.

questions.text: Is there a dedicated deadstock storage space, physically separated from the animal facilities?

options.text: Yes, but it is not physically separated from the live animals
Not relevant, deadstock is immediately processed

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of dedicated deadstock storage attracts vermin and creates unsanitary conditions.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Build dedicated, enclosed deadstock storage facility in dirty area, away from animal housing.

questions.text: Is the deadstock storage space located in the dirty area of the farm?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Deadstock storage in clean areas contaminates animal environment with pathogens and attracts disease vectors.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Relocate deadstock storage to dirty area. Maintain clear separation from animal facilities.

questions.text: Is the deadstock storage space enclosed and well maintained to prevent vermin, pets or wild animals from accessing the deadstock?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Open deadstock storage attracts flies, rodents, birds, and wild animals, spreading disease.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Enclose deadstock storage completely. Use sealed, vermin-proof containers with secure lids.

questions.text: Is the deadstock storage cooled?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Uncooled deadstock storage accelerates decomposition, pathogen multiplication, and odor issues.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install refrigeration in deadstock storage to slow decomposition and pathogen growth.

questions.text: Is the deadstock storage space cleaned and disinfected after each use?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Uncleaned deadstock storage accumulates pathogens and attracts disease vectors.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean and disinfect deadstock storage after each collection. Establish regular sanitation schedule.

questions.text: What happens with deadstock?

options.text: Deadstock is stored and collected by a rendering company

questions.help_text: Composting is a natural decomposition process for organic wastes. Burying might be prohibited in your country. Please be aware that these surveys are used around the world.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Improper deadstock handling methods increase disease transmission and environmental contamination risks.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement approved deadstock disposal method: licensed collection service, approved composting, or authorized burial/incineration.

questions.text: Is deadstock composted in a closed system?

options.text: Yes, dead animals are composted inside a building that can be completely closed
Yes, dead animals are composted outside, enclosed with e.g. plastic

risk_assessment.risk_description: Open composting systems allow pathogen survival and spread through leachate and vectors.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use only closed, properly managed composting systems that achieve pathogen-killing temperatures (>60C).

questions.text: How are dead animals buried/burned?

options.text: Dead animals are burned in an approved incinerator on the farm
Dead animals are buried in the appropriate soil on the farm

questions.help_text: Buried in appropriate soil: deep burial in pits away from a groundwater source.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Improper burial/burning may not destroy all pathogens and can contaminate environment.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Follow regulatory guidelines for depth, location, and methods. Ensure complete pathogen destruction.

questions.text: Can deadstock be collected by the rendering company without them entering the premises of the farm (e.g. from the public road)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Collection services entering farm premises bring external contamination risks.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Position deadstock storage at farm perimeter. Allow collection without collector entering clean areas.

questions.text: Does the farmer/farmworker change footwear when entering the deadstock area?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Not changing footwear when entering deadstock area spreads pathogens to other farm areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install footwear changing station at deadstock area. Use dedicated boots only for deadstock handling.

questions.text: Is deadstock manipulated with single-use gloves, or are hands cleaned and disinfected after the manipulation of deadstock?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Poor hand hygiene after deadstock handling transmits pathogens to clean areas and animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Require glove use and thorough handwashing after any deadstock contact. Install handwashing station at deadstock area.

questions.text: What type of feed is used on the farm?
questions.help_text: *Swill feeding might be prohibited in your country. Please be aware that these surveys are used around the world.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Home-mixed feed lacks quality control and may contain contaminants or inadequate nutrition, affecting pig health and disease resistance.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use commercially formulated feed from certified suppliers with quality assurance programs and regular testing.

questions.text: Does animal feed originate from a feeding company meeting specific hygienic requirements (e.g. Salmonella-free, heat treatment such as pelletizing)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Feed from uncertified companies may contain contaminated ingredients or inadequate biosecurity measures in production.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Source feed only from suppliers meeting international feed safety standards (GMP+, HACCP). Verify certifications regularly.

questions.text: Can the feeding company fill up the feed silos/storage without entering the clean area?
questions.help_text: The clean area is the area of the production site with restricted access, i.e. where only animals from the farm, persons after they have applied the hygienic measures in the hygiene lock, and farm-specific materials and vehicles are allowed. The dirty area comprises all other parts of the farm to which visitors, external vehicles, ... have access. The dirty area also includes the carcass storage facility.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Feed suppliers entering clean areas bring external contamination directly to animal facilities.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install feed storage accessible from farm perimeter. Allow silo filling without supplier entering clean areas.

questions.text: Does the feed supplier have access to the animal holding areas where direct contact with the pigs is possible?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Feed personnel accessing animal areas create direct disease transmission pathways.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Restrict feed supplier access to feed storage areas only. Never allow entry to animal housing.

questions.text: Is the water delivery system (incl. a water header tank) covered at all times?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Open water delivery systems allow contamination from birds, rodents, insects, and environmental debris.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Cover all water storage tanks and delivery systems completely. Install filters and maintain closed system.

questions.text: How frequently is a bacteriological analysis of the drinking water performed?

options.text: Less frequent than every two years
Never, I have a municipal water supply

risk_assessment.risk_description: Infrequent or absent water testing allows bacterial contamination to go undetected, causing disease outbreaks.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Conduct bacteriological water testing minimum quarterly. More frequent testing if issues suspected.

questions.text: At which location are the water samples for the bacteriological analyses taken?

options.text: Both at the source and the last drinker (farthest away from the source)
Other (e.g. drinker at the beginning of the line)

risk_assessment.risk_description: Inadequate water sampling locations miss contamination problems in distribution system.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Sample water at both source and end-point (farthest drinker) to detect distribution system contamination.

questions.text: Is a specific and well-functioning pass-through for materials entering the buildings of the farm (e.g. a UV cabinet for utensils and tools) used?
questions.help_text: Materials can be mobile phones, documents, pens, diagnostic tools, etc.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of material pass-through allows uncontrolled movement of contaminated items into clean areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install UV cabinet or disinfection pass-through for tools, documents, phones, and small equipment entering farm.

questions.text: Is there any equipment (small or large) shared with other farms that enter your farm and/or has contact with your pigs?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared equipment with other farms creates direct cross-contamination pathways between operations.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use farm-specific equipment only. If sharing unavoidable, implement strict cleaning and disinfection protocols.

questions.text: Are specific measures taken for the introduction of equipment from other farms?
questions.help_text: E.g. cleaning and disinfection, quarantine period at a specific location.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Uncontrolled introduction of shared equipment brings pathogens from other farms.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Quarantine and disinfect all incoming shared equipment. Consider equipment rental program with certified cleaning.

questions.text: Does the farm follow a written biosecurity plan?
questions.help_text: A biosecurity plan should at least contain the following elements: the critical aspects/risks associated with the farm, and prioritization of farm-specific biosecurity implementation with regular (at least annual) revisions for improvement.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Absence of written biosecurity plan leads to inconsistent practices and biosecurity failures.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Develop comprehensive written biosecurity plan. Train all staff and visitors. Review and update annually.

questions.text: Did the farmer and/or farmworkers receive training on biosecurity in pig production in the last five years?

options.text: Both have received training on biosecurity
Only one of them has received training on biosecurity
Neither of them has received training on biosecurity

questions.help_text: Training can be a diploma, e-learning courses, workshops, or webinars. The training can also be given by internal personnel as long as they have received certified training on their end. If you do not have any farmworkers, select answer option "Yes, both have received training on biosecurity" when the farmer has received training. If the farmer has not received training, select answer option "Neither of them has received training on biosecurity".

risk_assessment.risk_description: Untrained staff lack biosecurity awareness, leading to inadvertent breaches and disease introduction.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Provide biosecurity training to all personnel within past 5 years. Conduct annual refresher training.

questions.text: Are visitors obliged to notify and record their presence before entering the animal facilities?
questions.help_text: I.e. a closed gate so a visitor needs to call someone/ring a bell to get access, the obligation to sign a register book, ...

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unrecorded visitor access prevents disease tracking and creates accountability gaps.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement mandatory visitor registration system. Record name, date, time, and purpose of all farm entries.

questions.text: Is there a hygiene lock available that is always used by visitors when they enter the animal facilities?

options.text: There is a hygiene lock present, but it is not always used

questions.help_text: The hygiene lock is a room where, among others, you can change into farm-specific clothes/footwear and wash/disinfect your hands.

risk_assessment.risk_description: No hygiene lock allows visitors to enter animal areas with external contamination on clothing and footwear.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Construct proper hygiene lock with shower facility. Require all visitors to change clothing and footwear.

questions.text: Are all animal facilities only accessible for visitors through a hygiene lock?
questions.help_text: I.e. there are no alternative ways to enter the animal facilities. One must always go through the hygiene lock.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Multiple access points to animal facilities bypass biosecurity controls.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Make hygiene lock the sole entry point to animal areas. Block or remove alternative access routes.

questions.text: Is there a strict separation between the clean and the dirty area of the hygiene lock (e.g. by a physical barrier or a walkthrough shower)?
questions.help_text: The dirty area of the hygiene lock is where the farmworkers/visitors enter, store their clothes/footwear, and clean/disinfect their hands. In the clean area of the hygiene lock, they can put on farm-specific clothing and footwear. Physical barrier: e.g. wooden plank/bench.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of physical separation in hygiene lock allows contamination carryover from dirty to clean sides.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install clear barrier between dirty and clean sides of hygiene lock. Enforce strict separation protocols.

questions.text: Is there a shower facility and is it always used by visitors/personnel before they enter the animal facilities?

options.text: Only for visitors, not for personnel
There is a shower facility, but it is not always used

risk_assessment.risk_description: Absent shower facility prevents removal of pathogens from personnel before entering animal areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install functional shower facility in hygiene lock. Require showering for all personnel entering animal areas.

questions.text: Before being allowed to enter the farm, do visitors and farmworkers have to ...?

rows.action: wear available farm-specific clothes/bring clean clothes (if not available)
wear available farm-specific footwear/bring clean and disinfected footwear (if not available)

risk_assessment.risk_description: Inadequate hygiene practices (clothing, footwear, handwashing) allow pathogen transmission by personnel.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Enforce complete clothing change, dedicated footwear, and handwashing for all personnel. Provide farm-specific protective equipment.

questions.text: Are there farmworkers who have contact with pigs other than those on the establishment?
questions.help_text: Pigs at home, on other farms, wild boars, hunting, agricultural shows,...

risk_assessment.risk_description: Workers with external pig contact bring high-risk pathogens to your farm.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Prohibit staff from owning pigs or working on other farms. Implement minimum 48-hour pig contact restriction policy.

questions.text: Is the outside of the farm buildings (around the walls) paved and clean (i.e. the removal of weeds, waste, ...) so that there are no hiding places for vermin?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unpaved or dirty outdoor areas harbor pathogens and make cleaning impossible.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Pave all outdoor areas around buildings. Maintain clean surfaces through regular cleaning and drainage.

questions.text: Is a pest control programme in place on the farm?

options.text: A professional pest control company is hired periodically
The farm has its own periodical pest control programme
Pest control is performed only if an infestation/overpopulation is noticed (e.g. via rodent traps)
There is no pest control programme

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of pest control allows rodents, insects, and wild animals to spread diseases between areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement comprehensive pest control program with regular monitoring, baiting, and professional pest management services.

questions.text: Do pets or wild animals have access to the animal facilities (incl. the storage for feed and bedding material)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Pets and wild animals carry diseases and contaminate feed, water, and facilities.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Ban pets from farm premises. Install fencing to exclude wild animals. Maintain secure perimeter.

questions.text: Do birds have access to the animal facilities (incl. the storage for feed and bedding material)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Birds defecate in facilities, contaminating feed, water, and surfaces with pathogens.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install bird exclusion measures including nets, screens, and deterrent systems. Remove nesting sites.

questions.text: Are grids placed on all air in- and outlets?
questions.help_text: Grids that are small enough to keep rodents and small birds out.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unprotected air inlets and outlets allow entry of birds, insects, and contaminated air from outside.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install fine mesh screens on all ventilation openings. Maintain screens in good condition.

questions.text: Is the farm located in an area with a high or a low density of pigs?
questions.help_text: A region with a high density of pigs has an average pig density of >300 pigs/km at the municipality level. If there are multiple pig farms within a 3 km radius of your farm, you are most likely located in a high-density area.

risk_assessment.risk_description: High pig density areas increase disease pressure from neighboring farms and airborne transmission.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Enhance biosecurity measures in high-density areas. Consider air filtration systems and increased monitoring.

questions.text: Are there any other pig farms within a 500-metre radius (0.3 miles) of your farm?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Nearby pig farms create high disease risk through aerosol transmission, shared vectors, and environmental contamination.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement enhanced biosecurity. Maintain communication with neighboring farms about disease status. Consider air filtration.

questions.text: Is manure from other pig farms being spread on farmlands within a 500-metre radius (0.3 miles) of your farm?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Manure from other farms spread nearby increases pathogen exposure through aerosols, runoff, and vectors.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Monitor neighboring manure spreading activities. Enhance biosecurity during high-risk periods. Secure ventilation systems.

questions.text: Do transport vehicles carrying animals from other farms often (i.e. minimum once a day) pass on a road less than 100-metre (328 feet) from your farm (e.g. due to the location of a slaughterhouse in the neighbourhood, ...)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Transport vehicles from other farms passing nearby create aerosol disease transmission risk.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Maintain secure perimeter. Close windows and air inlets during vehicle passage. Enhance external biosecurity.

questions.text: Have wild boars (or their traces) been spotted within a 10-kilometre radius (6.2 miles) of your establishment?
questions.help_text: Establishment: the entire farm premises, including all indoor animal facilities and the entire outdoor area surrounding the farm.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Wild boar contact risk introduces serious diseases including African Swine Fever, Classical Swine Fever, and other pathogens.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install robust wild boar-proof perimeter fencing. Regularly inspect and maintain fence integrity. Report wild boar sightings to authorities.

focus_areas.name: Production Management
focus_areas.description: Prevent disease spread within the farm

questions.text: Is the farm enclosed by wild-boar-proof fences?
questions.help_text: A wild-boar-proof fence is a double row of fencing made from metal net or wire with a minimum height of 1.5m or a single solid fence made from metal, masonry, or other solid material with a minimum height of 1.5m.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of proper fencing allows wild boar and other animals direct access to farm, causing disease introduction.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install wild boar-proof fencing around entire farm perimeter (minimum 1.5m height, buried 50cm). Electrify if needed.

questions.text: Are the fences inspected on a regular basis (i.e. at least monthly) to identify breaches and repaired if needed?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unmaintained fences develop breaches, allowing wildlife and wild boar access.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Inspect fencing monthly for damage. Repair immediately. Document inspection results.

questions.text: Is there a treatment plan on the farm that is evaluated on an annual basis by a veterinarian/health advisor?
questions.help_text: Health advisor: any person who comes to the farm to help improve the health of the animals (e.g. nutritionist, consultant, ...).

risk_assessment.risk_description: Outdated treatment plans lead to inappropriate antibiotic use, treatment failures, and increased disease risk.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Review and update treatment plan annually with veterinarian. Document all changes and ensure staff training.

questions.text: Is a regular (i.e. at least once a year) evaluation made of the disease status of the farm (e.g. serology, trends in slaughterhouse findings, etc.) in consultation with a veterinarian/health advisor?
questions.help_text: Health advisor: any person who comes to the farm to help improve the health of the animals (e.g. nutritionist, consultant, ...).

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of disease monitoring prevents early detection of emerging health problems and disease outbreaks.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Conduct systematic health status evaluation quarterly minimum. Include production records analysis and veterinary assessment.

questions.text: Are runt pigs (stay-behinds e.g. due to unclear causes) and/or diseased pigs isolated from the healthy ones or is a strict euthanasia policy used?

options.text: Runt pigs are always isolated from the healthy animals
Runt pigs are sometimes isolated from the healthy animals
Runt pigs are not isolated, they always remain within their group
There is a strict euthanasia policy, so there are no/barely any runt pigs

risk_assessment.risk_description: Mixing sick/runt pigs with healthy animals facilitates rapid disease spread throughout the group.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Immediately isolate sick and runt pigs in dedicated hospital pen. Euthanize severely compromised animals promptly.

questions.text: What happens with the runt pigs after recovery?

options.text: They are put back into their original group
They are relocated to a younger age group
They are kept isolated from the other animals until they leave the farm

risk_assessment.risk_description: Returning recovered runt pigs to original groups reintroduces pathogens and may cause recurrence.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Keep recovered pigs isolated. Move to separate finishing group or euthanize if continued poor performance.

questions.text: Are diseased pigs consistently handled/visited after the healthy ones?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Treating diseased animals first spreads pathogens to healthy groups through contaminated equipment and hands.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Always handle and treat diseased/sick animals last. Change gloves and wash hands between groups.

questions.text: Are the sows washed before they are moved into the farrowing unit?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unwashed sows entering farrowing units bring external contamination to newborn piglets' environment.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Wash all sows thoroughly with soap and water before moving to farrowing unit. Focus on udder and legs.

questions.text: Are suckling piglets systematically transferred between sows (i.e. cross-fostering)?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Frequent cross-fostering increases disease transmission between litters and complicates disease tracing.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Minimize cross-fostering frequency. Only cross-foster within first 24 hours. Limit to balancing litter sizes only.

questions.text: Does cross-fostering of suckling piglets between different sows occur once or multiple times per lactation?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Excessive cross-fostering increases pathogen exposure and stress in piglets.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Limit cross-fostering to once per lactation period. Practice within first 24 hours of birth only.

questions.text: When does cross-fostering occur?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Late cross-fostering allows litter-specific pathogens to establish before mixing, increasing disease risk.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Cross-foster only within first 24 hours after birth, preferably within first 12 hours.

questions.text: How many times are the piglets routinely taken by hand (e.g. vaccination, castration, grinding of the teeth, tail docking, ear tagging, ...) between birth and weaning?
questions.help_text: Some of the manipulations mentioned in this question might be prohibited in your country. Please be aware that these surveys are used around the world. If multiple manipulations occur at the same moment, you can count this as one occasion.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Frequent piglet handling increases stress and disease transmission through contaminated hands and equipment.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Minimize piglet handling to essential interventions only (processing, treatments). Maintain hand hygiene between litters.

questions.text: Are materials/tools for treatment (e.g. castration blade, tail-docker, ear-tagger, injection needles) cleaned and disinfected or replaced between each litter?

options.text: Only some of the materials/tools are cleaned and disinfected or replaced

risk_assessment.risk_description: Unclean tools spread pathogens between litters, causing disease outbreaks in multiple litters.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean and disinfect all tools (needles, pliers, ear taggers) between litters. Use heat sterilization when possible.

questions.text: When castrating, are the castration blades/needles disinfected or replaced between different piglets?

options.text: The blades/needles are disinfected or replaced after each piglet
The blades/needles are disinfected/replaced after several piglets or different blades/needles per pen are used
The blades/needles are not disinfected or replaced until blunt

risk_assessment.risk_description: Contaminated castration equipment transmits blood-borne pathogens between piglets.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Use sterile, single-use blades for castration. If reusable tools used, disinfect thoroughly between each piglet.

questions.text: Is strict all-in management practised in each compartment of the nursery unit?
questions.help_text: All-in: the animals that move to the same nursery unit are moved there all at once and no new animals are introduced in the nursery unit before it is emptied.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Mixed-age groups in nursery allow continuous disease cycling and prevent effective all-in/all-out management.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Practice strict all-in/all-out by compartment in nursery. Never mix different age groups or batches.

questions.text: Are older piglets (from a different farrowing group) sometimes mixed with younger piglets?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Mixing older with younger nursery pigs allows disease transmission from more immune to naive animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Maintain strict age segregation. Keep age groups separated by minimum one week intervals.

questions.text: What is the maximal stocking density of a pen in the nursery unit?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Overcrowding in nursery increases disease transmission, stress, and reduces performance.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Maintain appropriate stocking density per industry standards (0.3-0.4 m/pig). Never exceed maximum capacity.

questions.text: Is the nursery unit physically separated (i.e. no direct contact possible) from the other pig units?
questions.help_text: I.e. there are no other animal groups present in the same building/area.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Nursery connected to other units allows disease flow between age groups and prevents effective isolation.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Physically separate nursery from other production areas. Install separate ventilation and access points.

questions.text: Is there a separate hygiene lock for the nursery unit?
questions.help_text: A hygiene lock is a facility, where among others, you can change into specific clothes/boots and clean/disinfect your hands.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared hygiene facilities between nursery and other areas create disease transmission pathways.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install dedicated hygiene lock for nursery area. Provide separate clean clothing and footwear.

questions.text: Is strict all-in management practiced in each compartment of the finishing unit?
questions.help_text: All-in: animals that move to the same finishing unit are moved there all at once and no new animals are introduced in the finishing unit before it is emptied.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Continuous flow finishing allows disease carryover between batches and prevents effective cleaning.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement all-in/all-out management in finishing unit. Allow minimum 3-day empty period between batches.

questions.text: Are different age groups strictly separated into different (i.e. physically separated) compartments/areas?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Mixed age groups facilitate continuous disease circulation and complicate health management.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Separate different age groups by minimum one-week intervals. Maintain strict age segregation.

questions.text: Are older slaughter pigs sometimes mixed with younger pigs?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Mixing age groups breaks biosecurity and allows disease spread from older to younger animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Never mix pigs of different ages. Maintain single-age groups from entry to exit in finishing.

questions.text: What is the maximal pig density of a pen in the finishing unit?

options.text: 1 or more m per slaughter pig (1.50 m or more per heavy slaughter pig)
0.70 to 0.99 m per slaughter pig (1.10 to 1.49 m per heavy slaughter pig)
0.60 to 0.69 m per slaughter pig (0.80 to 1.09 m per heavy slaughter pig)
Less than 0.60 m per slaughter pig (less than 0.80 m per heavy slaughter pig)

questions.help_text: "Regular" slaughter pigs are kept until they are between 90 and 115 kilograms live weight (between 200 and 250 pounds). Heavy slaughter pigs are those that weigh more than 115 kilograms live weight (more than 250 pounds).

risk_assessment.risk_description: Overcrowding in finishing increases disease risk, stress, and reduces growth performance.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Maintain proper stocking density (0.8-1.0 m/pig depending on weight). Monitor and adjust as pigs grow.

questions.text: Are different compartments/age groups present on the establishment?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Lack of compartment separation allows unrestricted disease flow between different age groups and production stages, enabling continuous pathogen circulation throughout the farm.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Establish clearly defined physical compartments for each age group or production stage. Install barriers and separate access routes to prevent cross-contamination between compartments.

questions.text: Between different compartments/age groups, are the following actions performed?

rows.action: Change into specific clothes per compartment/age group
Change into specific footwear per compartment/age group
Wash hands/change gloves per compartment/age group

questions.help_text: Compartment: a physically defined unit or area where one group of pigs is being kept (i.e. you can have multiple compartments of the same animal category). Often, physical contact is possible between the animals of different pens within this compartment.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Not changing clothing, footwear, or practicing hand hygiene between compartments allows personnel to mechanically transfer pathogens from contaminated to clean areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement strict hygiene protocols between compartments: change clothing, use compartment-specific footwear, and wash hands or change gloves before entering each new area.

questions.text: Are either disinfection baths and/or boot washers used between different compartments/units?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Absence of disinfection baths or boot washers between compartments allows pathogen carryover on footwear, one of the most common contamination vectors.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Install disinfection footbaths or boot washing stations at entrances to all compartments. Maintain proper disinfectant concentration and change solutions regularly.

questions.text: Which working sequence is used in normal circumstances?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Working from older to younger animals or having no sequence transfers pathogens from more contaminated older pigs to immunologically naive younger animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Always work from youngest to oldest animals. This prevents spreading established infections from older pigs to vulnerable young stock.

questions.text: Is the equipment that is needed for a specific animal category placed according to the working lines (work routine route) to avoid the equipment being used in any other age category?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Equipment not organized by working lines leads to cross-contamination as tools are inadvertently used across different age categories, spreading pathogens.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Organize and store equipment according to working lines. Use age-specific storage locations to prevent accidental cross-use of equipment between different animal categories.

questions.text: Are clearly recognizable (e.g. by colors) and separate materials/tools used for each unit or age group?
questions.help_text: This question concerns all units (if available): farrowing crates, nursery unit and finishing unit.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Using the same materials across different units without visual differentiation leads to accidental cross-contamination between age groups and production stages.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Implement color-coded equipment system (e.g., red for farrowing, blue for nursery, green for finishing). Use clearly recognizable visual markers to prevent cross-use.

questions.text: Are the pig sorting/driving panels easy to clean (e.g. plastic) and are they regularly (i.e. after every use or at least after every production cycle during the sanitary break) cleaned and disinfected?

options.text: Yes, the panels are easy to clean and are regularly cleaned and disinfected
The panels are easy to clean but are not regularly cleaned and disinfected
The panels are not easy to clean (e.g. wood) but are regularly cleaned and disinfected
No, the panels are not easy to clean (e.g. wood) and are not regularly cleaned and disinfected

risk_assessment.risk_description: Dirty or porous sorting panels (e.g., wooden panels) harbor pathogens that cannot be effectively cleaned, creating persistent contamination sources used across multiple pens.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Replace wooden panels with easy-to-clean plastic or metal panels. Clean and disinfect after every use, or at minimum after each production cycle during sanitary breaks.

questions.text: Are specific injection syringes and needles used for each age group?

options.text: Both syringes and needles are specific for each age group
Only the needles are specific for the age group

questions.help_text: This question concerns all units (if available): farrowing crates, nursery unit and finishing unit.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Shared equipment between multiple age groups without proper cleaning between uses creates direct pathogen transmission pathways across the entire farm operation.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Assign dedicated equipment to each age group. If sharing is unavoidable, implement strict cleaning and disinfection protocols after each use before moving to another age category.

questions.text: After how many pigs are the injection needles changed?
questions.help_text: This question concerns all units (if available): farrowing crates, nursery unit and finishing unit. If this differs per compartment/age group, please indicate the worst-case scenario.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Failure to implement all-in/all-out management allows continuous pathogen presence and prevents effective cleaning, making disease elimination impossible.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Convert to strict all-in/all-out management by compartment. Ensure complete depopulation before cleaning and allow proper empty periods for pathogen die-off.

questions.text: Are the pens/compartments cleaned after each production cycle?

options.text: All pens/compartments are cleaned after each production cycle
Only some of the pens/compartments are cleaned after each production cycle
The pens/compartments are cleaned after every couple of production cycles

questions.help_text: This question concerns all units (if available): farrowing crates, nursery unit and finishing unit.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Inadequate empty periods (less than 3 days) after cleaning do not allow sufficient drying time and pathogen die-off, risking immediate recontamination of incoming animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Maintain minimum 3-day empty period after cleaning and disinfection. Longer periods (5-7 days) provide better biosecurity. Ensure complete drying before restocking.

questions.text: Are the pens/compartments soaked with water before the start of the cleaning?

options.text: Never, I only practise dry cleaning

risk_assessment.risk_description: Uncleaned pens between batches harbor surviving pathogens in organic matter, biofilms, and surfaces, directly exposing new animals to disease from previous occupants.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean all pens thoroughly between batches using appropriate detergents. Remove all organic matter, then disinfect and allow proper drying time.

questions.text: Is detergent/soap added to the water during cleaning?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Cleaning without disinfection removes visible dirt but leaves viable pathogens on surfaces, providing false sense of security while disease risk remains high.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Always follow cleaning with appropriate disinfection. Use approved disinfectants at correct concentration and contact time. Ensure surfaces are clean before disinfecting.

questions.text: Are the pens/compartments disinfected after each production cycle?

options.text: All pens/compartments are disinfected after each production cycle
Only some of the pens/compartments are disinfected after each production cycle
The pens/compartments are disinfected after every couple of production cycles

questions.help_text: This question concerns all units (if available): farrowing crates, nursery unit and finishing unit.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Failure to clean walls and ceilings leaves biofilms and contamination in place, creating aerosol contamination sources that reinfect cleaned floor areas and new animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Include walls and ceilings in cleaning protocols. Use high-pressure washing to remove biofilms. Disinfect all surfaces, not just floors and pen partitions.

questions.text: Are the animal facilities fully dried before new pigs enter?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Inadequate disinfection contact time (less than 30 minutes) does not allow sufficient pathogen kill, leaving viable organisms that can infect incoming animals.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Ensure disinfectant remains in contact with surfaces for minimum 30 minutes, preferably longer. Check manufacturer recommendations for specific contact times.

questions.text: Is the efficacy of cleaning and disinfection checked (e.g. hygienogram, ATP-metry, swabs, ...)?
questions.help_text: A hygienogram is a quantification of the bacterial status of the environment with a contact plate.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Not removing organic matter before disinfection neutralizes disinfectants and creates protective barriers for pathogens, rendering the disinfection process ineffective.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Always clean thoroughly before disinfecting. Remove all feces, feed residue, and organic debris. Use detergents before applying disinfectants.

questions.text: Are the corridors and the loading area cleaned and disinfected after the pigs are moved?

options.text: Not cleaned nor disinfected after use

risk_assessment.risk_description: Inconsistent cleaning procedures between production cycles leads to variable biosecurity levels and allows disease persistence in inadequately cleaned areas.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Develop and follow written standard operating procedures for cleaning and disinfection. Train all personnel. Document completion of each step.

questions.text: Is equipment (e.g. sorting/driving panels, spades) cleaned and disinfected after their use?

risk_assessment.risk_description: Reusing contaminated mats without cleaning transfers pathogens from exiting to entering animals, defeating all-in/all-out biosecurity benefits.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean and disinfect all mats, slats, and removable equipment between batches. Consider heat treatment or high-pressure washing with approved disinfectants.

questions.text: Are the feeding systems (feed lines, troughs) cleaned and disinfected after each production cycle?

options.text: Cleaned and disinfected after each production cycle
Only cleaned after each production cycle
Cleaned but not after each production cycle (only occasionally)

risk_assessment.risk_description: Uncleaned feed systems harbor mold, bacteria, and old feed residues that contaminate fresh feed and can cause digestive diseases and reduced feed intake.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean and disinfect feed lines, augers, and troughs after each production cycle. Flush feed lines with cleaning solution and ensure complete drying.

questions.text: Is the feed silo/storage cleaned (and disinfected) on the inside?

options.text: Less than once every two years

risk_assessment.risk_description: Dirty feed silos accumulate mold, bacteria, and feed degradation products that contaminate all incoming feed batches, affecting multiple production cycles.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean feed silos at least annually, preferably more frequently. Inspect regularly for moisture, mold, and residue buildup. Use proper silo cleaning equipment and approved sanitizers.

questions.text: Is the drinking water system cleaned and disinfected on the inside between production cycles?

options.text: Less than once every two years

questions.help_text: This excludes the use of continuous low doses of disinfectant during production cycles.

risk_assessment.risk_description: Contaminated water systems develop biofilms and bacterial colonization that continuously expose animals to pathogens through drinking water, causing recurring health issues.
risk_assessment.recommendation: Clean and disinfect water systems between production cycles minimum. Use approved water sanitizers. Flush lines completely. Test water quality regularly to verify effectiveness.

notes.complete_questions: This JSON contains the complete 116 questions from Biocheck Pig 4.0 with corrected types, options, and conditional logic.
notes.conditional_logic: Conditional logic is implemented using 'conditional_logic' objects with 'if_answer' and 'then' properties.
notes.scoring: Each answer option includes a 'score' field (0-100) for calculating biosecurity scores.
question_types: single_choice: Radio buttons, one answer only
table_choice: Table with multiple rows of choices
notes.farm_type_dependent: Questions Q19, Q20, Q22, Q23 require farm type information from pre-assessment to determine skip logic.

critical.label: Critical Priority
critical.description: These risks represent severe biosecurity failures that can lead to catastrophic disease outbreaks.

high.label: High Priority
high.description: These risks represent significant biosecurity weaknesses that substantially increase disease probability.

medium.label: Medium Priority
medium.description: These risks represent moderate concerns that should be addressed to optimize biosecurity.

trigger_mechanism.rule: Display risk assessment when user's answer scores 50 points
trigger_mechanism.explanation: Any answer scoring 50 points or below indicates a biosecurity weakness requiring attention

improvement_plan_layout.ordering: Critical first, then High, then Medium
improvement_plan_layout.collapsible: Allow users to expand/collapse each priority section
improvement_plan_layout.action_tracking: Provide checkboxes to mark recommendations as completed

get_risk_assessment.returns: Single question's risk assessment with priority metadata

get_improvement_plan.returns: All triggered risk assessments grouped by priority

get_priority_summary.returns: Count of risks by priority level

translation_guidelines.risk_description: Maintain technical veterinary accuracy. Use formal professional language.
translation_guidelines.recommendation: Ensure actionable clarity. Use imperative verb forms (do this, implement that).
translation_guidelines.priority_labels: Translate labels but keep values as critical/high/medium in code.
translation_guidelines.characteristics: Translate while preserving biosecurity terminology precision.

quality_assurance.veterinary_review: All translations should be reviewed by veterinary professionals
quality_assurance.terminology_consistency: Use consistent translation for recurring technical terms
quality_assurance.cultural_adaptation: Adapt recommendations to local farming practices where appropriate

detailed_findings.grouping: By priority level, then by focus area

progress_report.timeline: Show improvement trajectory over multiple assessments

Use color codes consistently across application
Implement priority filtering in improvement plan view
backend_implementation: Validate all risk assessments against metadata rules
Use priority counts for statistics endpoints
Generate improvement plans using priority grouping
Track risk resolution status in database
mobile_app_considerations: Optimize risk description length for mobile screens
Use collapsible sections for long recommendations
Implement swipe gestures for priority filtering
Offline access to risk assessment metadata
